CONNECT-THE-DOTS
better pawn structure can give you a lasting initiative and dictate the course of action. In this game, once his pawns are doubled on the g-file, Black's kingside pawns lose their flexibility. White's control of the ...e7-e5 break makes it impossible for his kingside initiative to be challenged and makes the flank attack more powerful. The outcome of this game, played against National Master Larry Tamarkin, is a reminder that chess is not just a cerebral activity, but a sporting contest as well. Iwas in a clearly winning position, but drifted into time pressure and lost on time.
S. WEERAMANTRY - L. TAMARKIN
New York, 1991
1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.exd5 cxd5
This is the Exchange Variation of the Caro-Kann. There are many different variations, but you do not need to study them all just yet. You need only one line against each opening. You can always add others later.
4.Bd3 (D)
White positions his bishop on the long diagonal to h7, with an eye towards a future kingside attack. White's queen and bishop now control g4 and f5 respectively, taking away the natural After 6.Nf4 Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann) developing squares from Black's light-square bishop.
4...Nc6
Question: What is the obvious threat? Answer: To take the pawn on d4. Question: Of course. There is also a less obvious threat. What is that? Answer: Play ...Nb4 and trade the knight for White's bishop. Good. Black would love to trade off this powerful bishop. Question: Does White have a move to handle both threats? Answer: Push his pawn to c3. Correct. This builds a pawn chain and stops ...Nb4. Question: Now that we have seen the strength of c3, is there any disadvantage to this move? Answer: Yes. It takes away the c3 square from White's knight. Right. However, the positive outweighs the negative. Moves are seldom totally good or totally bad. You have to weigh the advantages and disadvantages.
5.c3 Nf6 6.Bf4 (D)
White prevents the ...e7-e5 break. Question: A general opening principle states: develop knights before bishops. Can you think of any reason why this principle is widely followed? Answer: Knights are short-range pieces, so they should be moved out early. Is it not true that you would get the knights out soon enough even if you took an extra move or two to first develop the bishops? Answer: Knights can attack center pawns. Bishops cannot. I must admit, I never thought of it that way. I suppose a bishop would have trouble attacking acenter pawn without getting captured itself! However, that is not the reason for the principle. There is one logical square for each knight in the opening - on the third rank and towards the center. Other squares are less desirable. The reason for the principle "knights before bishops" is that it is generally clear where the knight should go. It is not always clear which square is best for a bishop - it has more choices. Therefore, it would make more sense to wait and see how your opponent develops his pieces before deciding where to place your bishop. In playing Bf4, White is clearly violating this principle. Do not take any principles for granted. Examine each and every position on its own merits. There are two words that you should be wary of - one is ALWAYS, and the other is NEVER. Knowing when a principle does not apply is the mark of a good player. Here the justification for moving the dark-square bishop before either knight is quite clear.
6.Nd2 would simply block in that bishop which is needed to guard e5. The immediate 6.Nf3
would also not be successful as it allows Black to set up an annoying pin with ...Bg4.
6...Bg4 (D)
Black decides to play ...Bg4 anyway, in order to attack White's queen. An interesting alternative is to fianchetto the king's bishop with 6...g6 and 7...Bg7. Question: Blocking the attack on his queen with Nf3 would clearly ruin White's earlier strategy. How else can he handle the attack? Answer: Be2. No. There is no logic behind this move. Question: There is one overpowering reason why White should not play Be2. What is it? Answer: You have already developed the bishop to d3. Why move it back? Exactly. This bishop is on a great square. Do not retreat a developed piece without good reason. Question: Give me another suggestion that handles Black's attack. Answer: f3. Question: There is a drawback to this move. What is it? Answer: It takes the f3 square away from the knight. Question: Yes. Can you find a better move? After 10.Se5 (7".Qd7 variation) Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann) Answer: Qc2. Question: The queen-and-bishop battery on the long diagonal is strong. However, there is an even better move. What is it? Answer: Qb3. Finally!
7.Qb3 (D)
7.Qb3 seizes the initiative by threatening the b7-pawn. This is the square that was weakened
when Black's bishop went to g4 on the previous move. Black cannot ignore this attack. Question: How should Black handle the attack on the b7-pawn? Answer: Push it up to b6. No. That weakens the light squares unnecessarily. Answer: Defend it with ...Qd7. This is quite playable. However, Black has to be careful not to fall into a trap: 7...Qd7 8.Nd2 e6 9.Ngf3 Be7 (9...Bd6 is better) 10.Ne5. (D) Question: Now, should Black capture the knight or retreat his queen? Answer: Take the knight. Oops. You just fell into the trap. Exercise 11-1a: After 7...Qd7 8.Nd2 e6 9.Ngf3 Be7 10.Ne5 Nxe5, what is the trap that Black has fallen into? Exercise 11-1b: What should Black do instead? Back to the game. Defending the b7-pawn with the queen is the right idea, but not from d7.
7...Qc8 (D)
Question: Can you guess the next few moves for each side? Answer: White should bring out both knights and then castle. Black should play...e6 and ...Be7. Isn't this simple? Both sides are making natural developing moves. Chess is easy when you pay attention to the fundamentals! Your answer is exactly how the game proceeded:
8.Nd2 e6 9.Ngf3 Be7 10.O-O
To this point, both Tamarkin and I have been following a well-trodden path. The nature of chess competition has changed dramatically over the years. A sound knowledge of opening theory is essential if you are to succeed at the master level in modern tournament play. Much of the work is done before ever coming to the board.
10...Bh5 (D)
After 12.Ne5 (10...O-O variation) Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann) The idea behind playing ...Bh5 is to play ...Bg6 and neutralize White's pressure along the b1- h7 diagonal. Castling before playing ...Bh5 is less effective: 10...O-O 11.Qc2 Bh5 12.Ne5. (D) Taking the knight now would cost Black a pawn: 12...Nxe5 13.dxe5 Nd7 14.Bxh7+. With White's knight on e5, opposing bishops with 12... Bg6 will allow White to trade knight for bishop, rather than exchanging bishops. By playing ...Bh5 before castling, Black threatens to place his bishop on g6 before White plays Ne5. Should White attempt to rush Ne5, he would be saddled with an inferior pawn structure:
10...O-O 11.Ne5 Nxe5 12.dxe5 Nd7. (D)
Black now has c5 available for his knight, and he can still oppose bishops with ...Bh5-g6. Small differences in move order can have a profound effect on a position.
11.Qc2 Bg6 12.Bxg6 (D)
After 12...fxg6 (variation)
[diagram]
The trade of bishops cannot be avoided. White prefers to initiate the bishop trade in order to double Black's pawns. Question: Which way should Black recapture and why? Answer: With the h-pawn, to give the rook an open file. Question: Good. What about the other option? Answer: Capturing with the f-pawn will break up Black's pawn structure and leave him with a backward pawn on e6. Yes. It is a question of pawn structure. (D) Every time pawns break up into small groups, we refer to each group as a pawn island. The more pawn islands there are, the weaker the pawn structure. Certain squares become difficult to defend. If Black recaptures with the f-pawn, his pawns will break up into three islands. The base of the pawn chain will shift from f7 to e6, making the e6-pawn backward and vulnerable because it is situated on White's half-open e-file. On the other hand, ifBlack recaptures with the h-pawn, then f7 provides a solid foundation for the entire structure.
12...hxg6 13.Rae1 (D)
After 13.aael
[diagram]
Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann) Question: Why should White play Rae1 when he could just as easily move the other rook over? How do you decide which rook to activate when there is only one open file? Answer: The a1-rook is not doing anything on the other side of the board. Question: True, but what about the other rook? Is it any better on f1? How is this rook going to participate in the game? Answer: You could double rooks on the e-file. If your intention is to double rooks, it makes no difference which rook you move first. Furthermore, doubling rooks is most effective when targeting a backward pawn. Doubling in this position is the wrong strategy because there is no target. Question: When I played 13.Rae1, I already had a plan for activating the f1-rook. What was my plan? Answer: To move your bishop and knight out of the way, and push the f-pawn. Excellent! Imagine for a moment that the bishop and knight have moved off the f-file and I have advanced my pawn to f4. Both rooks are now active. In the early middlegame, rooks belong on open files or behind advancing pawns.
13...O-O (D)
Now the opening is over. Both sides are fully developed. At this stage of the game, finding the appropriate long-term plan is critical. Plans do not just appear out of thin air - the pawn structure dictates the plan. Connect-the-dots The pawns establish the boundary of your territory. Your entire middlegame plan can be based upon how these boundaries are drawn. To illustrate this, let's play connect-the-dots. If these dots represent the pawns, you can see the board is divided into two triangles. White's pawn chain is pointing towards the kingside and he is clearly controlling more space in that sector. It will be difficult for Black to challenge this superiority without bringing more pieces over from his queenside. However, Black's pawn structure makes this difficult because the pawn on e6 restricts the flow from one side to the other. He has a very narrow funnel to move his pieces through. Build your attack in the sector where you have more space. If you understand this structure, you will appreciate that White has a natural kingside attack with a high probability of success. You will also realize the importance of preventing the move ...e6-e5. If Black cannot advance his pawn to e5, he will be unable to free his position. Look at the pieces White has concentrated on that square - a pawn, a rook, a knight, and a bishop. Black's pawn is not going anywhere! A remarkable feature about this position is that not one of Black's five kingside pawns can move without serious consequences. The g6-pawn cannot move without endangering the king; the pawn behind it cannot move at all; the e6-pawn is frozen in its tracks; the d5-pawn is blockaded; and if the f7-pawn moves, the entire kingside pawn structure will collapse! Once you determine that the pawn structure is not going to change, you can organize your attack more effectively. A methodical approach is essential. Start with a concept, then consider specifics. The danger of not following this order is that you will make random moves, and never put together an organized attack. First, decide which squares your pieces should occupy in order to maximize their attacking potential. Second, determine how to get your pieces to the ideal squares. Next, establish whether or not your opponent can prevent your pieces from reaching the preferred destinations. Finally, consider whether or not your opponent can ignore your plan completely and launch a counterattack of his own. If you think through these four steps and are satisfied that your ideas are valid, then go ahead with your plan. After 13...O-O
[diagram]
Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann) Now, let's apply this process to the game position. (D) Step One... Question: Where should White place his pieces for an attack on the king? Answer: I like one knight on g5, and the other on f3. Question: That certainly brings the knights into the attack. What about the other pieces? Answer: I like a rook on h3 and the queen on h4, threatening mate on h8. Excellent. Even if this does not lead to mate, an invasion on the h-file will present many problems for Black. Question: How about the pawns? Will they be used in the attack? Answer: No. Do not push the h-pawn. It will only block the file for the queen and rook. Good. The h-file must be kept clear. What about the other kingside pawns? We have already noted that f4 is a desirable move. It not only frees the f1-rook, but also helps to control the e5 square. As for the g2-pawn, it could go to g4 to keep Black's knight out of h5. Step Two... Question: Do our pieces have a clear path to these squares? Answer: Yes. The f3-knight can go directly to g5 and the d2-knight can then go to f3. Answer: The e1-rook can go to e3, then h3. Answer: The queen can go to d3, then g3, then h4. Excellent. And we can play f4 once we move the bishop. That was easy! Step Three - can Black stop these moves? Obviously, he can try to keep the knight out of g5 by playing ...f6, but that would destroy his kingside pawn structure. He cannot prevent the d2-knight from going to f3. And, there is no reasonable way for him to attack the squares the rook will be using. That just leaves the queen. Question: Can Black stop the queen from occupying h4? Answer. Yes, because his bishop on e7 can attack h4. Question: True. Can we counter that? After 14...£sh5 Answer: Yes. That's why we want our knight on g5. Actually, the knight would be very useful on e5. We could put our bishop on g5 instead, and set up a trade of bishops to secure h4 for the queen. A key feature of this position is that Black's kingside pawn structure is fixed, thus closing the center. As a result, White's plan to move his pieces over to the flank cannot easily be disrupted. Finally, Step Four. Question: Can Black ignore White's plans and mount his own attack? Answer: Yes. He may be able to attack down the c-file. Thank you! This is his half-open file which is the logical place to look for play. Question: Which pieces are sitting on that file? Answer: The two opposing queens. Question: Right. If you see that, you will notice a tactic Black could use. Answer: He can play ...Nxd4 if White moves his f3-knight. Do you see the value of using this process? You need to follow all these steps. It is not enough to focus on your moves alone. When you play chess, you are playing two games in your head: the moves you can make, and the moves your opponent can make. Failing to anticipate your opponent's counterplay will ruin your own plans.
14.Qd3
White moves his queen off the c-file and inches it towards h4.
14...Nh5 (D)
Black is playing on the kingside, but this is not a good strategy. White's attack is too strong. Instead, Black should consider moving his f-rook away to create an escape route for his king. It is very hard to plan an active defense because Black's kingside pawns cannot move. In similar positions, acommon strategy is to expand on the queenside with ...b7-b5, ...a7- a5, and ...b5-b4, then initiate a trade of pawns on c3. This trade would saddle White with a backward pawn, which would then become a target for Black. This strategy is called a minority attack - two pawns are attacking three. Here, unfortunately, such a plan would be too slow compared to White's direct assault on the king. After 15±g5
[diagram]
Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann)
15.Bg5 (D)
White moves his bishop out of danger and offers a trade of bishops. Should Black accept, White would recapture with his knight, paving the way for the pawn to advance to f4.
15...Qd8
Black sets up a battery attacking the bishop. Question: How should White handle the attack without changing his plan? Answer: Capture the bishop. No. It is better to support the bishop with Qe3 and let Black make the trade.
16.Qe3 Bxg5 17.Nxg5 (D)
White recaptures with his knight. By having Black initiate the trade, White has gained a tempo. Meanwhile, his queen keeps inching towards h4.
17...Qf6?
A careless move. Black probably intended 18...Qf4 to set up a queen trade, hoping to turn back the attack.
18.f4 (D)
After 18,f4 After 19.g4 Finally! So much for ...Qf4. White's pawns on d4 and f4 now have a stranglehold on the e5 square. With the center firmly under control, White's flank attack will be more difficult to repel. Question: What is the immediate threat? Answer: g4, trapping the knight. Yes. The only way to save it is to move the queen, creating a retreat for the knight.
18...Qe7 19.g4 (D)
This move appears to violate another important principle, in this case a middlegame principle: do not push the pawns in front of your castled king. Question: Under what circumstances might you be justified in ignoring this principle? Answer: When your opponent has no counterplay against your king. Question: Correct. But what would stop your opponent's counterplay? Answer: A closed center. Exactly. When the center is fluid, do not move the pawns in front of your castled king. When the center is closed, they are free to move.
19...Nf6 20.Qh3 Rfc8 (D)
After Z0,..Rfc8 After 21...Sd6 Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann) Black intends to run his king to f8 and block a back-rank check with ...Ng8.
21.Rf3
The f-rook is heading to the h-file. Using the e-rook would have been more accurate so that the f4-pawn would remain protected.
21...Qd6 (D)
This is where I lost the game. I took fifteen minutes to make my next move, even though the time control was game in thirty! There really was no need to spend so much time, because I had already seen a beautiful combination. Question: Do you see it? Answer: The queen checks on h8, setting up a knight fork on f7. Absolutely correct. Isn't this a pretty move? How many chances do you get to stick your queen right in front of the enemy king? This is an example of a magnet combination attracting Black's king into a fork. There was no need to look for something better, because this move leads to the win of a pawn and destroys Black's kingside pawn structure. Unfortunately, I was reluctant to trade queens and kept searching for a checkmate.
22.Qh8+ Kxh8 23.Nxf7+ Kg8 24.Nxd6 (D)
After 24.Nxd6 White is ahead in material and has the superior pawn structure.
24...Rc7 25.Rxe6 Rf8
Black decided not to take the g4-pawn because White would reply with Rg3, skewering the knight to the g6-pawn.
26.h3 (D)
White is up two pawns and should win easily. He simply has to consolidate by doubling his rooks and improving the position of his other knight. The wasted time on move 22 left me with only moments on the clock and we were playing without a delay. I did manage to make ten or more additional moves from this position, but my opponent hung on three pawns down in the endgame, and my flag fell! After this unhappy experience, I can give you the following advice: If you see a position where you are clearly winning, there is no need to search for the perfect move. After 10...Qxe5? (7,..Bd7 variation) Weeramantry - Tamarkin 1991 (Caro-Kann)
ANSWERS
Exercise 11-1a: After 7...Qd7 8.Nd2 e6 9.Ngf3 Be7 10.Ne5 Nxe5? (D), what is the trap that Black has fallen into? Answer: 11.dxe5 wins material. Black's knight is under attack, but should it take the time to move away, 12.Bb5 would pin Black's queen to his king. Exercise 11-1b: What should Black do instead? Answer: Instead of 10...Nxe5, Black can survive by retreating his queen with 10...Qc8. This loses time, but at least it does not cost him any material.
REVIEW
Themes Controlling the central pawn break (6.Bf4). Developing knights before bishops (discussion after 6.Bf4). Proper timing of moves (6.Bf4 vs. 6.Nf3 and 10...Bh5 vs. 10...O-O) Whether or not to initiate a trade (12.Bxg6 and 15...Qd8 16.Qe3). Pawn islands (12...fxg6 variation). Choosing which rook to place on a file (13.Rae1). The relationship between pawn structure and space (discussion after 13...O-O). General planning in the middlegame (discussion after 13...O-O). Minority attack (discussion after 14...Nh5). Advancing pawns in front of the castled king (19.g4). Magnet combination (discussion before 22.Qh8+). Advice Moves are seldom totally good or totally bad. You have to weigh the advantages and disadvantages. There are two words that you should be wary of - one is ALWAYS, and the other is
NEVER.
Do not retreat a developed piece without good reason. Small differences in move order can have a profound effect on a position. The more pawn islands there are, the weaker the pawn structure. In the early middlegame, rooks belong on open files or behind advancing pawns. Build your attack in the sector where you have more space. Start with a concept, then consider specifics. Failing to anticipate your opponent's counterplay will ruin your own plans. When the center is fluid, do not move the pawns in front of your castled king. When the center is closed, they are free to move. If you see a position where you are clearly winning, there is no need to search for the perfect move. Weeramantry - Urbaneja 1991 (Sicilian Grand Prix Attack)
LESSON 12
[diagram]
IT'S NEVER OVER
ou may tend to think of drawn games as dull games, but this is not always the case. Iam going to show you a game I drew that was far from dull. It is a good example of "chess as a struggle." The initiative shifts back and forth between myself and my opponent, National Master Juan Carlos Urbaneja Navarro, a leading player from Venezuela.
WEERAMANTRY - URBANEJA
New York, 1991
1.e4 c5 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.f4
Another Grand Prix Attack. We first looked at this opening in Lesson 7 in my game against Mitchell Goldberg. Do you know how this opening got its name? It was used frequently by British players in the Cutty Sark Grand Prix tournaments in England in the 1970s. The inspiration, however, were the games of the Danish GM Bent Larsen in the 1960s, but he liked to play f2-f4 on move 2.
3...g6
The fianchetto formation is a popular alternative to 3...e6.7
4.Nf3 (D)
After 4".e6 (variation) After 7.Qxd4 (4...e6 variation) A common mistake in this position is for Black to reply with 4...e6. (D) Question: Why is 4...e6 a mistake? You do not have to look for an exact sequence. Think back to previous lectures and give me a general answer. Answer: It leaves holes on the dark squares. Good. I am glad you remembered about color weaknesses. By playing both ...e7-e6 and ...g7- g6, Black opens up two diagonals, but has only one dark-square bishop. He is creating weaknesses that cannot be controlled. As the game goes on, and Black gets better piece development, he may be able to cover some of the weak squares with other pieces. At this stage of the game, however, he is not in a position to do that. Question: How do you prove that 4...e6 is bad? Answer: Play 5.d4 cxd4 6.Nxd4 Nxd4 7.Qxd4 (D), preventing Black's bishop from going to g7. Your analysis is correct. In order to take advantage of weaknesses like this, you must open the position, and thus be able to target the dark squares. Instead of trading knights, Black would do better to play 6... Bg7. (D) After 7.Ndb5 (4...e6 variation) Weeramantry - Urbaneja 1991 (Sicilian Grand Prix Attack) Question: How should White proceed? Answer: Push e5. That will help White control the dark squares. Good. e5 is definitely part of White's plan, but there is a more important move to be played first. Answer: Be3. This is a good developing move, but is too passive. Look for a more active move. Answer: Play Ndb5. (D) Yes! 7.Ndb5 is much stronger than 7.Be3. With Black's bishop already committed to the other diagonal, he cannot stop White's knight from jumping into d6. Then e5 makes a lot more sense because it anchors the knight on an advanced outpost square. Occupying d6 would also bury Black's c8-bishop, giving White a substantial lead in development. All things considered, Black cannot use the move order 4...e6 in this opening. Back to the actual game where Black played the correct move.
4...Bg7 5.Bc4
White's light-square bishop usually goes to c4 or b5. Both moves are reliable. In general, the bishop goes to b5 if Black has moved his d6-pawn, and to c4 if he has not.
5...e6
Now ...e7-e6 is quite playable as White cannot open the position with d2-d4. After 6,f5
[diagram]
After 7..,gxf5 (6,..exf5 variation)
[diagram]
After 7.d3 (6,..gxf5 variation)
[diagram]
6.f5 (D)
This pawn sacrifice is an attempt to seize the initiative by disrupting Black's pawn structure. If Black takes with his e-pawn, White can take back without losing control of the center (6...exf5
7.exf5). It is clear that Black should not capture again with 7...gxf5 (D), because he will be
saddled with doubled and isolated f-pawns where his extra pawn would be of little use. If Black takes with his g-pawn on move 6, then White must continue with 7.d3 (D), keeping his pawn on e4 to prevent Black from playing ...d7-d5. Of course, if Black takes on e4, White will take back with the pawn (7...fxe4 8.dxe4). So long as Black has a pawn on e6, White must maintain a pawn on e4. After 9...Na5 Weeramantry - Urbaneja 1991 (Sicilian Grand Prix Attack) Either way, White's superior development gives him excellent compensation for the sacrificed pawn. Back to the game. My opponent did not take the pawn and instead played the move recommended by theory.
6...Nge7 (D)
Black prepares to castle and puts more pressure on the f5 square.
7.fxe6 dxe6
While this move has been played by many grandmasters, playing 7... fxe6, keeping open the possibility of ...d7-d5, is the better move.
8.d3 O-O 9.O-O
We have reached the end of the opening. There are a few pieces left to be developed, but now the fun begins.
9...Na5 (D)
Black wants to trade off the c4-bishop and double White's c-pawns. This plan is inefficient because it involves three knight moves to capture a piece that has moved only once. The extra time needed to carry out this maneuver helps White to complete his development before Black does. Meanwhile, Black's bishop is still languishing on c8, impeding the coordination of his rooks. After 10,Qel
[diagram]
After ll.dxc4 (10,,,Sxc4 variation)
[diagram]
10.Qe1 (D)
White uses the dark squares to transfer his queen to the kingside, a common plan when attacking the fianchetto. This move also avoids a queen trade should White have to recapture on c4 with his pawn. Black could continue with his plan of trading knight for bishop, but, as we will see, the doubled c-pawns actually help White, for example 10...Nxc4 11.dxc4. (D) White's c4-pawn now controls d5. As a result, his e-pawn is free to advance to e5. This clears the e4 square for his knight and strengthens the kingside attack. In addition, White will be able to use the d-file for his rook and increase his control of the center. Question: What is the best placement for White's pieces to conduct a kingside attack? Answer: Play Qh4, then Bh6. Yes. The queen belongs on h4 from where it controls the key dark squares h6 and g5. White can decide whether to place his bishop on g5 or continue on to h6 keeping g5 open for the f3- knight.
10...h6 11.Qh4 Nec6 (D)
After ll... ec6

After 12.Ng5
[diagram]
Weeramantry - Urbaneja 1991 (Sicilian Grand Prix Attack) Black challenges White's queen, hoping to dislodge it from h4. White cannot retreat his queen because 12.Qh3 will be met with the discovered attack 12...e5. However, White has a surprising move. Question: Can you find it? Answer: Bg5. If Black takes the bishop, the knight will take back, threatening Qh7#. Bravo!
12.Bg5 (D)
Amazingly, the h6-pawn does not prevent White from playing this move. The first time I used this idea was against International Master Dr. Hans Berliner, in the
1975 Eastern Open. Dr. Berliner was a former World Correspondence Champion best known as
the programmer of HiTech, which was once the strongest computer chess program in the world. If the queen moves away, then Bxh6 shatters Black's defenses and opens g5 for White's knight. Remember the squares h4, h6, and g5. They are the key to the dark-square attack against Black's fianchetto. At this point, I was walking around confident that I had this game already won. The problem with chess is, it's never over! After forty-five minutes' thought, Urbaneja came up with an ingenious defense. Question: What is Black's clever defensive maneuver? After 13...*fd4+ Answer: ...f6. In some ways this does stop the attack, but it creates a new weakness on g6. After Bxh6, Black's position is collapsing. This is a tough sequence to find, so I will give you a clue. The only way to survive the attack is for Black to get his queen to g7. My opponent just sat there until he figured it out. Icould not believe it! Answer: 12...Bd4+ 13.Nxd4. Hold on. White is not going to take the bishop. He would just play Kh1 instead. But you are right that the d4 square has something to do with it. Time for another hint. Question: What is the one move we are all assuming Black cannot play? Answer: ...hxg5. Of course. But that is a wrong assumption!
12...hxg5! 13.Nxg5 Qd4+ (D)
14.Kh1
White can also get out of check with 14.Rf2. Exercise 12-1: Which move, 14.Kh1 or 14.Rf2, gives White better winning chances?

for his queen.
15.Qxh6 Qg7
End of attack. Black suffered a little damage, but he was able to regroup and defend. Now the attacker must retreat and reorganize before starting again.
16.Qh4
White does not want the queen on h3 where it would be exposed to a discovered attack from the c8-bishop. Still, it is not clear how White should continue the attack. I have a sad story to tell. This is not the only time I have had this position. A little more than a year after this game was played, I got to the same position in a thirty-minute game against five- time U.S. champion Grandmaster Gata Kamsky. Kamsky played 16...Ne5. (D) I failed to find the best continuation and ended up losing. The consensus in the postmortem analysis was that I had excellent chances had I played Rf6!. Back to the game.
16...Nxc4 17.dxc4 Ne5 (D)
After 18... xc4 (variation)
[diagram]
Question: Why does ...Ne5 make sense? Answer: It attacks a pawn. It attacks the c4-pawn and centralizes the knight. What else can you tell me about the e5 square? Answer: It is an outpost. Remember, the square in front of an isolated pawn is a great outpost. Put a homing device on that square and jump right in there.
18.Rad1
White is answering the attack on the c4-pawn with a counterattack. This developing move sets up an indirect defense to the threat of ...Nxc4. (D) Exercise 12-2: If Black tries 18...Nxc4, how does White respond?
18...f6 19.Nf3 Nxc4
Black has re-established material equality, but here comes the second wave of the attack.
20.e5! (D)
After 21,£te4 Weeramantry - Urbaneja 1991 (Sicilian Grand Prix Attack) Advancing the pawn sets up a discovered attack on Black's knight. If Black accepts this pawn sacrifice with 20...Nxe5 21.Nxe5 fxe5, White will either win Black's queen or deliver a forced mate. Exercise 12-3: After 20...Nxe5 21.Nxe5 fxe5, how should White continue? Of course, Black did not take the pawn.
20...Ne3
A more challenging move, Black forks White's rooks. This was not unexpected.
21.Ne4 (D)
Now you see the real point of 20.e5. It is a clearance move. If the knight reaches f6, White's attack becomes unstoppable. His last piece will have entered the fray with devastating effect. Meanwhile, Black can take only one rook at a time. Why bother trying to save either one? Leave them there and let him have his pick! Question: If Black plays 21...Nxf1, how should White reply? Answer: Just play Nxf6+. Good. This is stronger than recapturing on f1. What happens now? Answer: Black plays ...Kf7, then White checks with the other knight. Yes. 22...Kf7 23.Ng5+ Ke7 24.Qc4 gives White an overwhelming attack. After 23,.. xf8
[diagram]
Question: But, what if Black decides to return material with 22...Rxf6 instead of moving his king? Answer: White will take back with his pawn, attacking the queen. Right. Question: After 23.exf6 Qc7, how does White continue? Answer: 24.Ng5. Excellent. Black cannot stop all of White's threats. Now if Black instead takes the other rook with 21...Nxd1, White will again play 22.Nxf6+ Rxf6 23.exf6. After 23...Qh7, White simply trades down into an endgame where he can force the promotion of his f-pawn: 24.Qxh7+ Kxh7 25.Rxd1 g5 26.Ne5. Black did not take either rook. Instead, he counterattacked with...
21...g5
Now both rooks are hanging, as is the queen! In situations like this, forget about retreating anything. Press on with the attack and sacrifice the next piece.
22.Nfxg5 fxg5 23.Rxf8+ Kxf8 (D)
Unfortunately, all these moves had taken me a very long time, and my flag was hanging! I had a minute left to get to move thirty. Back then, we did not have the luxury of increment or delay.
24.Qf2+ Nf5 25.Qxc5+ (D)
After 28*. c6 Weeramantry - Urbaneja 1991 (Sicilian Grand Prix Attack) Now I am winning. If Black's king runs to g8 or e8, 26.Nf6+ Kf7 27.Rd8 Ne7 28.Qb5 Nc6 29.Qf1 sets up a winning discovered attack along the f-file.
25...Ne7 26.Rd8+ Kf7 27.Nd6+
Other good alternatives are 27.Nf6 and 27.Qb5. However, the text move, if played correctly, leads to a forced win.
27...Kg6 28.Qc3 Nc6 (D)
In time trouble, I missed a forced win. Exercise 12-4: Find White's winning line after 28...Nc6.
29.g4
Expecting Black to capture my rook, Itried to set up a mating net. But Black cleverly stays away from 29...Nxd8? as 30.Qd3+ leads to a mate in three: 30...Kh6 31.Qh3+ Kg6 32.Qh5#.
29...Nxe5?
This is also a losing move. Black should play 29...Qxe5 instead.
30.Nxc8?
One mistake after another! 30.Qh3 wins easily. There is no excuse for trading this powerful knight for a bishop that has not even moved. But this was the last move before time control, and After 34...Qdl+ I just could not think of anything else.
30...Qf6 (D)
I was so relieved to have reached time control that at first I did not realize the danger I was in. The position has changed, and Black has taken over the initiative. White's king on h1 is in more danger than Black's king on g6. White can no longer protect the rook and f1 at the same time.
31.Qd4 Rxc8
This rook sacrifice deflects White's rook from guarding d1. Black can now force a perpetual check.
32.Rxc8 Qf1+ 33.Qg1 Qf3+ 34.Qg2 Qd1+ (D)
35.Qg1 Qd5+ 1⁄2-1⁄2

REVIEW
Themes Weak color complex (4...e6 variation). Pawn sacrifice for initiative (6.f5 gxf5 7.d3). Pawn sacrifice for structural advantage (6.f5 exf5 7.exf5 gxf5). Attacking the dark squares around Black's castled king in a fianchetto formation (10.Qe1;
11.Qh4; 12.Bg5).
Accepting doubled pawns to control central squares (10...Nxc4 variation). Reorganizing the attack (16.Qh4 through 20.e5). Square clearance (20.e5). Advice Open the position to exploit weak squares. Advance a pawn to clear a square for a piece. Try approaching a target from different angles. Whenever possible, defend actively and counterattack. Sacrifice to gain the initiative. Sacrifice again to maintain it when necessary. When two pieces of the same value are attacked, it may be a waste of time to move either one - your opponent can only capture one piece at a time. Manage your time efficiently. Serious time trouble can spell disaster. __________
7 See Lesson 7, Strike While the Knight Is Cold.

31.Kg2 R8a7?

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 d6 3.d4 exd4 4.Qxd4 Nc6 5.Bb5 Bd7 6.Bxc6 Bxc6 7.Nc3 Nf6 8.O-O Be7
9.Nd5 Bxd5 10.exd5 O-O 11.Bg5 (D)
White has secured a considerable advantage in space. His pieces are occupying five ranks, while Black is confined to three. The extra space gives White's pieces greater mobility. The difference in the two bishops is particularly striking.
11...c6
Black attempts to break this stranglehold by changing the pawn structure. A better option is to attack the bishop with 11...h6, setting up a simple combination should the bishop retreat to h4: 12.Bh4 Nxd5, winning a pawn.
12.c4
White fully intends to maintain a pawn on d5, preventing Black from activating his bishop along the a3-f8 diagonal.
12...cxd5 13.cxd5 Re8 14.Rfe1
White takes the first step in activating his rooks: occupy an open file.
14...a5
Black moves the a-pawn to free his rook from defensive duty, but moving it one space forward to a6 is preferable as the pawns would stay connected.
15.Re2 Rc8?
A mistake. Black should remove any possibility of a back-rank mate by playing 15...h6.
16.Rae1
The second step is now complete: White doubles his rooks on the open file. Black is now in grave danger. If White captures on f6, Black will be forced to take back with his g-pawn, exposing his king.
16...Qd7 (D)
(D8) Adams - Torre 1920 Black moves the queen off the back rank to coordinate his rooks and guard against the immediate threat. However, Black's back-rank weakness still remains.
17.Bxf6
This initiates a winning combination featuring a series of queen offers based on the threat of a back-rank mate.
17...Bxf6
Black has an interesting alternative in 17...gxf6. Exercise D8-1: If 17...gxf6, White can try to win material with 18.Rxe7. Does this work?
18.Qg4!
White offers his queen in an attempt to deflect Black's queen away from its protection of e8.
18...Qb5
Naturally, 18...Qxg4 allows a forced mate: 19.Rxe8+ Rxe8 20.Rxe8#.
19.Qc4
A second attempt at deflection.
19...Qd7
Black must maintain his queen on the a4-e8 diagonal.
20.Qc7!
Yet another attempt to force Black's queen off the diagonal. This is the most striking of the three queen offers as White's queen plants itself directly in Black's face. Still, White's queen cannot be touched.
20...Qb5 (D)
Despite White's best efforts, Black's queen still occupies the a4-e8 diagonal. White must find a new idea to avoid repeating moves.
21.a4!
The key move. Exercise D8-2: What happens if White plays 21.Qxb7 in yet another attempt at deflecting Black's queen?
21...Qxa4 22.Re4
This follow-up move is essential. If White resumes his attempts at deflection with 22.Qxa5, Black simply plays 22...Qd7 23.Qc7 Qb5, repeating moves.
22...Qb5 23.Qxb7 (D)

(D9) Nakamura - Fluviá Poyatos 2007 The first impression is that White's king is in serious danger, but a closer examination reveals that Black's threat of ...Qg5+ can be easily parried. Black has three pawns for a bishop, but his pawns are on the queenside and are not useful in attacking White's king.
33.Qb5 Qxd4 34.Qe5
White centralizes his queen and offers a trade. Black has no immediate checks.
34...Qd8
A queen trade is out of the question, for White's bishop pair will easily dominate Black's pawns in an endgame.
35.Rd2
The rook cannot be captured because of White's mate threat on c7.
35...Bd7
Black's pieces are forced to retreat even further.
36.Rd4
This move keeps control of the game and guarantees equality. However, 36.Rxd7 would generate winning chances as White's bishop pair is superior to Black's rook.
36...e6+ (D)
After 39...JU7 Black finally gets in a check. White's king has the choice of advancing or retreating.
37.Kxh5
The king fights back. White is not afraid to capture this pawn; his pieces are well coordinated and can control Black's key attacking squares.
37...Be8+?
The fact that White's king is wide open with no pawn cover mesmerizes Black into believing that he is winning. The more realistic course is to settle for a repetition with 37...Qe8+ 38.Kh4 (38.Kh6 Qf8+) 38... Qd8+ 39.Kh5 Qe8+.
38.Kh6
White's king continues to move up the board. The lack of communication between Black's queen and rook, coupled with White's control of key lines of attack, ensures that the king will be safe.
38...Qe7
Black searches for a checking square...
39.Rf4
...and White calmly shuts him down.
39...Bf7 (D)
Black shields the f8 square and prepares to check White's king.
40.Qf6

40...Qf8+ 41.Kh7 Kb8 42.Rf2 e5
Black is probably quite frustrated at not finding a way to checkmate a king that appears to be defenseless. He misses the opportunity to force a draw by repetition, here and on the previous move, with 42...Rg6 43.Bxg6 Bg8+ 44.Kh8 Bf7+. As a result, White now reaps a full point, an apt reward for coordinating his pieces well in defense.

13.Qb3

14.Qe3

ANSWERS -COORDINATION/CONTROL
Rotlewi-Rubinstein 1907 Exercise D1-1: If White chooses to block with 21.Ne4 instead, how does Black proceed? (D) Answer: Black plays 21...Qh4, threatening mate on h2. White now has two choices: 1) 22.h3 Rxd3!, undermining the protection of the knight. After 23.Qxd3 Bxe4, White's queen cannot guard all the threats: a) 24.Qxe4 Qg3 25.hxg4 Qh4#; b) 24.Qb3 Be3 interferes with White's defense of the third rank and forces him to give up his queen in light of 24...Qxh3#. 2) 22.g3 Qh3 (threatens ...Rxd3) 23.Bc2 Rxc2 24.Qxc2 Bxe4+ with mate to follow. D. Byrne-Fischer 1956 Exercise D2-1: Show how Black meets 18.Bxe6. (D) Answer: This leads to a smothered mate with 18...Qb5+ 19.Kg1 Ne2+ 20.Kf1 Ng3+ 21.Kg1 Qf1+ 22.Rxf1 Ne2#. Exercise D2-2: After 37.Ke1 (D), find a mate in four moves for Black. There are two ways to do this. After 19.Bf3 (variation) Answer: 1) 37...Re2+ 38.Kd1 Bb3+ 39.Kc1 Ba3+ 40.Kb1 Re1#; 2) 37...Bb3 38.Qh8+ Kxh8 39.Nxg6+ Kg7 40.Nf8 Bf2#. Bareev-Kasparov 1991 Exercise D3-1: If White tries to defend with 19.Bf3, how does Black win? (D) Answer: Black sacrifices the exchange with 19...Rxf3 20.gxf3 Qg5+ 21.Kh1 Bxh3 22.Rg1 Qh4 (threatens ...Bf1#) 23.Rg2 Bxg2+ 24.Kxg2 Qxf2+ and the mating attack with queen and bishop cannot be stopped. 27.Be5, mate will soon follow, for example 27...Qe7 28.Qg5 Rg8 29.Qxg8#.
Exercise D14-3: After 27.Nxd5, Black can try to defend with 27...Ng8. How should White continue? (D) Answer: White sets up a bishop check on e5 by removing the f7-pawn as a potential blocker:
28.Nxf7+! Rxf7 29.Be5+ Nf6 30.Nxf6 Bxf6 31.Qxf6+ Rxf6 32.Bxf6#.
Glossary
GLOSSARY
Active defense: When the defender chooses to employ a counterattack as a defensive technique rather than set up passively and attempt to cover his weaknesses. Active piece: A piece that is developed and is actively participating in the conduct of the game. Active pieces provide the basis for attack. Advantage, material: A preponderance in piece value of one side over another. See point count. Advantage, permanent: An advantage in material or pawn structure. Such advantages tend to be lasting. Advantage, positional: An advantage in time, space, mobility, pawn structure, or the control of critical squares. Advantage, temporary: An advantage that may gradually disappear during the course of a game, such as a lead in development. Back rank: The first rank for each player. The back rank becomes vulnerable late in the game if the rooks do not provide adequate coverage. Backward pawn: A pawn that constitutes the base of a pawn chain and whose forward movement is controlled by one or more enemy pawns on adjacent files. It is weak because it cannot be protected by other pawns. The weakness is significant only when it is subject to a frontal assault. Bad bishop: A bishop that is hemmed in by its own pawns. This occurs as the result of pawns on the color of the bishop's diagonal being immobilized by enemy pawns or pieces. Base of a pawn chain: The rearmost pawn in a chain is referred to as the base. It is the weakest link because it is not defended by another pawn. Battery: A lineup (on a single file or diagonal) of two or more pieces that move the same way, usually directed at a critical point in the enemy position. For example, the battery Qc2/Bd3 directs a two-piece attack against the h7 square. Bind: If a player is so constrained by enemy pieces that he finds it difficult to make useful moves, he is said to be "in a bind." See squeeze. Blockading square: The square directly in front of an isolated or backward pawn. The blockading square can also serve as an outpost square because a piece on that square cannot be chased away by pawns. Break: A pawn move that offers to trade pawns in order to increase control of space or free a cramped position. Broad pawn center: Three or four center pawns abreast. Indicates very aggressive intentions. The player facing such a center must play to restrain it and break it up. Also called "the big center." Buried piece: A piece that is hemmed in by its own pieces and pawns, and will have trouble finding a way to play an active role. Such a piece can also hinder the development of other pieces. Castle long; castle short: Castling on the queenside; castling on the kingside. Center break: A situation in which two or more pawns abreast on the fourth rank are attacked by an enemy pawn that seeks to disrupt this formation. Center fork trick: A series of moves in which one sacrifices a knight for a center pawn, knowing that the sacrificed piece will be recovered by a pawn fork and the opponent's central pawn structure destroyed in the process. Clearance move: A move that frees an occupied square for use by another one of your pieces. The new piece can put the vacated square to better use. Closed center: A center which is locked or fixed. See locked center and fixed center. Closed game: A game in which the center is closed. The piece that has the best mobility in such positions is the knight. See closed center. Combination: A precisely calculated sequence of forcing moves that leads to a permanent advantage. Compensation: What one gets in return for giving up something of value. One may sacrifice material or accept a structural weakness such as doubled pawns. Compensation for such sacrifices consists of acquiring an advantage of a different nature. Connected rooks: Two rooks on the back rank are connected when there are no other pieces between them. The power of the rooks is greatly enhanced in such situations. Consolidate: Sometimes it is necessary to "put one's house in order" before continuing with active operations. Consolidation may consist of adding extra protection to critical pawns or squares, improving piece placement, or taking care of king safety. Coordinated pieces: Pieces are coordinated when they work in concert, either to defend or to attack. They may protect each other, complement each other in attack, or supplement each other by covering a large number of critical squares. Dark-square bishop: The white bishop that starts on cl, or the black bishop that starts on f8. They always travel on dark-colored squares. Decoy: An offer of material in order to induce an enemy piece to change position. Destructive sacrifice: A type of sacrifice where you destroy the pawn cover or other piece protection around the enemy king. It usually signifies a point of no return. Development: Moving a piece out early in the opening to a square where it will play a more active role. Discovered attack: When a piece moves out of the way to expose an attack by the piece it was masking. Discovered attacks are dangerous because the piece that moves away can do so with impunity. Double attack: When a player makes two simultaneous threats, it is referred to as a double attack. It should be distinguished from a fork in that both attacks need not threaten the immediate capture of material. See fork. Glossary Doubled pawns: When two pawns of the same color occupy squares on the same file, they are said to be doubled. They are generally weak because they lack mobility. However, they can also be useful because they permit the use of an adjacent file. Draw: A tie game (neither player wins). A draw awards a half-point to each player and is scored as such when (1) there is insufficient mating material; (2) there is a stalemate; (3) a three-fold repetition of position is claimed; or (4) there is mutual agreement. Draw offer: A offer which, if accepted, ends the game and splits the point. The proper way to offer a draw is to say "Draw?" and make your move before starting your opponent's clock. You should not make a draw offer when your opponent is on the move. Dynamic play: Play is said to be dynamic when there are frequent structural changes that require a continual revision of strategy. This is usually brought about by tactical threats or significant changes in pawn structure. Exchange, the: The trade of a minor piece for a rook. The player who trades the minor piece is said to "win the exchange." Exchange sacrifice: This occurs when a player willfully gives up a rook for a minor piece in return for some form of compensation. See compensation. Expansion: Expansion increases the space that is directly under one's control. It is achieved by pushing pawns forward in an attempt to enlarge the boundaries of your territory. Fianchetto: The development of a bishop to g2, b2, g7, or b7. An Italian term that means "on the flank." Fixed center: A center which is occupied by multiple pawns and where some opposing pawns block each other. Pawn movement ispossible but not without being subject to capture. See closed center. Fixed pawn structures: Pawn structures with little or no mobility. The lack of pawn play makes it easier to predict strategy. Flag, hanging: The red flag on an analog chess clock is lifted slowly by the minute hand when a player has three minutes left to complete the moves needed to reach time control. When it reaches the final seconds, it is said to be "hanging." When it falls, the game may be forfeited. Flank attack: An attack on either the kingside or queenside. A flank attack has a greater likelihood of success when the center is closed. Fluid pawn structure: Pawn structures where further pawn movement is likely. Strategy is difficult to predict because changes in pawn structure often entail changes in strategy. Focal point: A weak square in the vicinity of the king which is targeted by the attacker and which the defender will find difficult to protect. The presence of more than one focal point makes an attack stronger. Fork: A form of double attack whereby a single piece threatens two pieces simultaneously. Frontal assault: A direct assault on an enemy pawn located on the same half-open file as one's heavy pieces. GM; IM; FM: Grandmaster; International Master; FIDE Master. Titles awarded by the Fédération Internationale des Échecs (FIDE), the governing body of international chess competition. Good bishop: A bishop that is not hemmed in by its own pawns; a bishop with adequate scope. Half-open file: A file on which only one side has pawns. Such a file is closed to one player, open to the other. The player to whom it is open can amass heavy pieces on it and attack the enemy pawns. Hanging piece: A piece that is left unprotected and is subject to immediate capture. Hanging pieces will ruin the best strategy! Heavy pieces: The rooks and queens; major pieces. Sometimes called heavy artillery. Hypermodern strategy: A system of development that concentrates on controlling the center from a distance, rather than occupying it early with pawns. Inactive piece: A piece that is not actively involved in the conduct of the game. Initiative, the: The prerogative to control the course of action. To gain the initiative, you make a threat that your opponent must meet. To retain the initiative, you continue to operate with threats. Interference move: A move that obstructs the line of attack of an enemy piece. Isolated pawn: A pawn that stands alone without friendly pawns on adjacent files. It is generally weak because, like the backward pawn, it cannot be protected by other pawns. It is particularly vulnerable if it is subject to a frontal assault. Knight on the rim: A knight that is placed on the a- or h- files, or on the back rank. Unless it is performing aspecific task, its future is "dim." It may get trapped, or have trouble getting back to a centralized position. Light-square bishop: The white bishop that starts on f1 or the black bishop that starts on c8. They always travel on light-colored squares. Locked center: A center which is occupied by multiple pawns and the opposing pawns are interlocked. No pawn movement is possible. Magnet combination: A sequence of moves in which a winning attack is set up by drawing a piece to a vulnerable square. This is often done with a sacrifice. Also known as a Combination of attraction. Major piece: A rook or a queen. See Heavy pieces. Maróczy Bind: When White sets up a formation with pawns on c4 and e4 against the Sicilian Defense, he is said to have a "Maróczy Bind." The pawns suppress Black's freeing maneuver ...d5. This formation was introduced by the Hungarian grandmaster Géza Maróczy. Mating pattern: A move sequence in the middlegame or endgame that contains a recognized pattern for executing checkmate. Minor piece: A bishop or a knight. Glossary Minority attack: Attack by a pawn minority against a pawn majority, usually on the queenside. The idea is to force a pawn trade that leaves the opponent with a weakened pawn structure. Mobility: Being able to move. Time and space are two essential components of mobility. Open file: A file that is not occupied by pawns of either color. Major pieces have good mobility when placed on open files. Open game: Positions that are characterized by few center pawns and many open lines. They usually arise from openings where White begins with 1.e4. Long-range pieces have good mobility in such positions. Outpost: A safe square near enemy territory that is protected by one's own pieces and is subject to effective occupation. Passed pawn: A pawn that is unopposed by enemy pawns on its own file and the two adjacent files. Such a pawn is a candidate for promotion. Pawn center: Commonly refers to pawns that may occupy any of the four central squares (d4, e4, d5, e5). Pawns on adjacent files are also considered to be part of the center if they are connected to pawns that occupy these squares. Pawn chain: Two or more pawns of the same color standing adjacent on a diagonal. Only the rearmost pawn in the chain is not protected by another pawn. See base of a pawn chain. Pawn contact: Opposing pawns are in contact when they can capture each other. Maintaining pawn contact maintains the tension in a position, keeping open more options. Capturing resolves the tension. Pawn island: A cluster of pawns of the same color that is separated from the next pawn by at least one open file. The more islands, the weaker the pawn structure. Pawn storm: The action of advancing one or more pawns against the enemy king with the intent of breaking up his pawn cover. It is commonly used when the two players are castled on opposite sides of the board. Pin, absolute: A tactic whereby a piece is attacked and rendered immobile because moving it would expose the king to check. Pin, relative: A pin wherein the pinned piece may elect to move but its movement would lead to a loss of material or other unfavorable outcome. Point count: The prescribed value of each piece: Q=9, R=5, B=3, N=3, R=1. An advantage in the point count denotes superiority in material. Position: The disposition of the pieces on the chessboard at any given time. Positional mistake: A mistake that has no direct tactical consequences but still leads to a disadvantage by surrendering control of critical squares, losing time or space, or incurring structural weaknesses. Positional sacrifice: A sacrifice that yields no immediate tactical gain but still leads to a positional advantage. Quiet move: Sometimes played during an attacking sequence, aquiet move does not contain an immediate threat but sets up another, more aggressive move. Quiet moves can be the most deadly moves of all. Rating: The measurement of a player's performance, calculated by a generally accepted formula administered by an official organization such as FIDE (the Fédération Internationale des Échecs) or the United States Chess Federation (USCF). The USCF rates its players on a scale from 0 to 3000 (or more). A typical novice rating is 1000; a master rating is 2200 and higher. Redeploy: To maneuver a piece so that it has access to another square, file, or diagonal where it will be more effective. Restrain: To control the movement of enemy pieces in order to prevent them from getting active play. Rook lift: A maneuver that involves moving the rook off the back rank and up a few squares. The intent is to swing the rook over to another file so that it may assist in an attack without being impeded by its own pawns. Running: Moving the king rapidly from one sector of the board to another in order to evade an attack. Scope: The scope of a piece refers to the number of squares it has access to. A piece hemmed in by its own pawns is said to have limited scope. Sector: One way to look at the board is to divide it into three sectors: the queenside (a-, b-, and c-files), the center (d- and e-files), and the kingside (f-, g-, and h-files). Learning to focus on each sector separately will help to formulate strategy. Skewer: A tactic whereby an enemy piece that stands in front of another along a rank, file, or diagonal is attacked and thereby compelled to move. This exposes the piece behind it to capture. Space count: A numerical system whereby the number of squares that each player attacks in the other player's half of the board is counted. A square may be attacked more than once. Each time it is attacked, one point is allocated. The player who is ahead in the space count has greater mobility. Squeeze: The exploitation of a bind by gradually increasing the pressure on an opponent's position. This is accomplished by creating new threats until the defender is unable to meet them all. Strategy: Formulation and execution of a long-term plan, designed to improve one's position. Symmetrical pawn position: A position in which the pawns on both sides are on the same files. Symmetrical position: A chess position in which, if the board were to be folded in the center, all opposing pieces of the same kind would overlap. Symmetrical positions tend to lead to equality, unless the player on the move can find a way to break the symmetry advantageously. Tactic(s): A mode of action characterized by the use of threats to win material or to checkmate the opposing king. They are said to be "the means to an end" - the means to realize the culmination of a strategy. Tempo: A unit of time in chess. The plural is "tempi." The best method for gaining time is to develop with a threat. Glossary Tension: A position in which pieces and/or pawns square off against each other without capturing. In such positions, good nerves and exact calculation are essential for survival. Theoretical move, or "theory": A move recommended by one or more authorities on the theory of best opening play. Transposition: A transposition occurs when a position (usually an opening position) is arrived at through a different order of moves than normal. The player who is alert to possibilities of transposing to favorable opening positions has an extra weapon at his disposal. Trap: A sequence of moves that relies solely on tactics and frequently disregards strategic considerations. Traps usually succeed when one is not alert. They seldom work against the more experienced player. Value, dynamic: The value of a piece in a given position. This may be lesser or greater than the static value. Value, static: The given value of a piece. See "point count." Zugzwang: A situation in which the requirement to move on a player's turn can only result in a worsening of the player's position.
ABOUT THE AUTHORS
FIDE Master Sunil Weeramantry is a pioneer in the field of curricular chess instruction and a nationally acclaimed educator with more than four decades' experience teaching and developing award-winning chess programs. Beginning in 1979, Sunil developed a comprehensive chess program at Manhattan's Hunter College Campus Schools, a leading laboratory school for talented and gifted students, where chess is a required subject for all students in kindergarten through fourth grade. Founder and Executive Director of the National Scholastic Chess Foundation, Sunil directs programs at over one hundred other schools and community programs in New York and Florida and, through a series of workshops presented across the United States, instructs classroom teachers on how to teach chess. Sunil served as Chairman of the Chess in Education Committee of the U.S. Chess Federation (USCF) for 10 years. He currently serves on the Scholastic Council and is a vocal advocate for the broader benefits of chess. A two-time New York State Champion, Sunil is better known these days as the stepfather of GM Hikaru Nakamura, one of the world's elite grandmasters. Sunil is co-author, along with Alan Abrams and Robert McLellan, of Great Moves: Learning Chess Through History (Mongoose, 2017), a blended learning text that teaches chess and social studies. Edward Eusebi is a Candidate Master in both over-the-board and correspondence chess. He has served chess as a coach, organizer, tournament director, and website content editor.

ROUND ONE
1. Szabo-Geller
(Catalan Opening) I have long suspected, when ever the books I have read began discussing darksquare weaknesses or an attack on the dark squares, that the subject under discussion was not only beyond my understan ding, but beyond the author's as well. "Certainly,", I would say to myself, "it must be true that the enemy dark squares will be weak if his pawns stand on light squares and he loses his dark square bishop. But if he then removes all of his pieces from the dark squares, what will be left for me to attack?" Such was my line of reasoning, until the day I realized that a weakness of the dark squares is also a weakness of the pieces and pawns on the light squares. Light square weaknesses are also possi ble, resulting in a weakening of the enemy pieces and pawns on the dark squares ---as occurred, for example, in the Geller - Najdorf game in Round 13. The point of an attack on the dark squares is that, by placing my pawns and pieces on the dark, I attack my opponent's pieces and pawns on the light. The Szabo - Geller game pro vides a clear example of the me thod of exploiting a darksquare weakness; and the combination which was possible after Black's 24th fairly begs to be included in a textbook, taking place as it does entirely on light squares.

c7-c5
d7-d5 Nimzovich never used to ad vance his c-pawn to cS without need; he hoped that, after he gave White doubled pawns by means of the exchange at c3, sooner or later he could induce White to play d4-d5, after which he could establish his knight at c5. A lot of water has gone un der the bridge since, and the modern master puts no great stock in that far-otf prospect of capi talizing on the doubled c-pawns. Instead, the immediate counter attack on the center with every means available has become one of the standard ideas for Black in the Nimzo-Indian.

8. a2-a3

10. Bd3:c4
Nb8-c6 Bb4:c3 d5:c4 Qd8-c7 Today, this position has been studied as thoroughly as were the Muzio and Evans Gambits a century ago. What are the basic features of this position, and how does the evaluation of those features give rise to the further plans for both sides? The placement of White's pieces radiates a great deal of poten tial energy, which ought to be [3] converted into kinetic-White must set his center pawns in motion, activating both his rooks and his deeply-buried darksquare bishop. The most logical plan would seem to be the advance of the e-pawn, first to e4, and then to eS, to drive Black's knight from f6 and lay the groundwork for a kingside attack. Black in turn must either pre vent the e-pawn's advance or counterattack the white pawn center, which will lose some of its solidity the moment the pawn advances from e3 to e4. In this game, Reshevsky com bines both of Black's ideas to achieve a favorable disposition of his forces, while Najdorf does not put nearly enough vig or into the execution of his plan.
11. a3-a4
Of all the possible continu ations that have been used here, this one may well be the least logical: it resolves only one minor problem, the development of the queen' s bishop- and to a poor square, at that. The pawn at cS will find defenders eas ily enough, and the bishop will find itself out of the action. That outflung pawn at a4 will not be a jewel in White's posi tion either. 11.

18. a2-a3
Qd8-a5 Nd7-b6 Bc8-d7 Stahlberg decides to rid his position once and for all of the threat of a black pawn advance to a3. This move deprives the square b3 of pawn protection, but it also strengthens the po sition of the pawn at b2 and generally of the whole constel lation a3-b2-c3. The next stage of the game - roughly to move 30- consists of skillful maneuvers from both sides, inducing weaknesses, White's preparation for e4-e5 and Black's for .. d7-d5 or • . f7- f5, and mutual prevention of these breaks. 18. 19 . 23. Nd4-f3
Ra8-d8 Bd7-c8 Nb6-d7 Nd7-f6 Rd8-d7 Rd7-e7 The next two moves are some what unusual, both for White and for Black: Black concen trates maximum firepower against the pawn at e4, an assault which White tries to divert by threat ening to take on d6. It is en tirely characteristic that, in order to carry out this idea, White can find no better re treat square for his central ized knight at d4, the pride of his position, than back to its original square g1, since all other retreat squares would in terfere, in one way or another, with the coordination between his pieces. This seems an appropriate time to impart to the reader the sec ret of the d6-pawn in the King's Indian Defense. This pawn, al though backward on an open file, proves nevertheless a tough lit- [12] tle nut to crack, because it is so hard to reach. It might seem that nothing could be simpler than dropping the knight back from d4, but the problem is that White needs his knight precisely on d4, where it observes the squares bS, c6, e6 and fS, and neutralizes the power of the bi shop at g7. Only after White has taken precautions against all of Black's possible attacks ( ..a4- a3, . • Bc8-e6, . • f7-f5) can his knight allow itself to leave the center; but meanwhile Black has time to regroup. So the weakness of the d6-pawn turns out to be largely fictive. Modern methods of opening play allow for many such fictive weak p,awns, but it was precisely this 'permanent" weakness at d6 which so long condemned the King's In dian to the list of dubious open ings.
24. Nf3-g1
The knight will return, five moves later, to help the pawn on e4 cross the Rubicon. The pawn could have been pushed at once, but that would have given up con trol of the fS square; Black's bishop could go there, and after 24 eS BfS, White would have had to sacrifice his queen by taking the knight at f6 with his pawn - but that would win for White . The simple 24 • • de, on the other hand, would give Black excellent play. White could have taken the a pawn here, but at too great a price: White needs his darksquare bishop as much as Black does. Boleslavsky's 24th move is an invitation to White's rook to cap ture that long-disputed point at last; after 25 • • Nb6, however, Black's knight enters c4. Stahl berg's decision is most probably the correct one: before proceed ing with the siege of the d-p,awn, he exchanges off the "Indian ' bi shops. 24.

9. Geller,_Euwe
{Nimzoindian Defense) One of the tournament's best games, and the recipient of a brilliancy prize. White initia ted a powerful attack on the king by sacrificing his c4-pawn. This attack gave Geller every hope of success, provided Black held to the traditional sort of queen side counterattack. Euwe, how ever, carried out two remarkable ideas: 1) utilizing his queen side lines of communication for an attack on the king's wing, and 2) decoying the enemy's forces deep into his own rear area, with the aim of cutting them off from the defense of their king. It's a most diverting specta cle to watch White' s pieces in their frontal assault on the king, burrowing further and further, while Black is transferring his forces by roundabout routes.
1. d2-d4 Ng8-f6
2. c2-c4 e7-e6
3. Nb 1-c3 Bf8-b4
4. e2-e3 c7-c5
s . a2-a3 Bb4:c3+
6. b2:c3 b7-h6
7. Rf1-d3 Bc8-b7
8. f2-f3
A small but significant opening subtlety: Black substituted .. b6 and . . Bb7 for the more usual . . Nc6 and .. O-O; and White, who failed to notice in time to react correctly with 7 Ne2, must now spend an extra tempo preparing e3-e4. Such details should never be underestimated, but neither should they be overvalued. Occa sionally it is said that White's advantage consists of his right to the first move: should he lose a tempo, then, the advantage must necessarily pass to Black. Prac tically speaking, however, the ad vantage of playing White boils down to greater freedom in selec ting a plan to suit one's tastes; once the game has settled into its ordained track, the loss of a single tempo is not always so serious. 8.

White therefore secures fS before advancing his f-pawn. It would be senseless to defend the pawn at c4 now: that pawn was doomed by White's fifth move.

Remember that in his lifetime he played more than seventy games with Alekhine, the most feared attacking player of (17) our time.
16. b6-b5!
The beginning of a remarkable plan. Clearly, any defensive ma neuvers on the kingside are fore doomed, since they involve pieces with an inconsequential radius of activity ( .. Rf7, . . Qe7, etc. ) . But Black does have another de fensive resource, and that is counterattack! The bishop at b7, the rook at c8, and the knight at c4 are all well-based; all that remains is to bring up the queen. The basis for this counterattack is Black's preponderance on the central squares. With 16 .. b5, Black reinforces the knight on c4 and opens a path for the queen to b6 . Still, one cannot help feeling that his operations are too little and too late . ..

Having played 11 Bb2, however, White can go ahead with his c3-c4, either at once or after the pre liminary 12 de be; so Black's re ply is not merely useful, but al most obligatory. The next phase of the struggle is defined by the new pawn structure: already it has much less to do with the tastes and preferences of the two players than it has to do with their choice of opening. White will set his f- and e pawns in motion, creating a passed d-pawn and combining the advance of these central pawns with an attack on the f-file. Black, with three pawns to two on his right wing, cannot do too much with them for the moment, since he must first battle the white bishop pair and central preponderance. 11.

Not yet; and, meanwhile, White needs only two or three moves ---Nc3 and Rbl, for example -- to take over all the key points on the queenside, and then to pick up the c5- or the e7-pawn. The knight's poor placement at a8 helps White greatly in the execution of this plan. 27.

(Old Indian Defense) d2-d4 Ng8-f6 c2-c4 d7-d6 " 3 . Nb1-c3 e7-e5 A radical means of avoiding both the Samisch and the Four Pawns ' Attack. Whatever White plays , the pure Samisch setup is now unattainable : for example , after 4 d5, Black is by no means obliged to fianchetto his bishop, but may play instead 4 • • Bf5 , and if 5 f3 e4. 39. Bronstein-Euwe
(Nimzoindian Defense) Generally, it makes sense to sacrifice a pawn, sometimes even a piece , in order to keep the en emy king in the center and assail it with rooks and queen. However, two general classes of such at tacks must be distinguished : in the first category, the king is kept to the e ighth rank, hemmed in by its own pawns and pieces ; whi le in the second category, the king is driven out to the sixth rank -- somet imes even to the fifth -- and attempts to find shelter on one wing or the other. ofTheth e prlaetsetnert game is an example type . The defender ' s chief resource is a cool head , and my opponent made full use of his here . At one point , I had to break off my calculations in order to ask myself : Just who is attack ing whom here? During the game, and afterwards as wel l , I was unable to shake the feeling that somewhere I had had a win. Perhaps some concrete variation did flicker momentarily through my mind , but it tarried not . . . In any event , neither I , nor the commentators ( Euwe, Naj dorf and Stahlberg) have been able to find an improvement for White, which would mean that my promising piece sacrifice was not enough for a win. Perhaps the win may yet be found in analys is ; but even if I did not get the point , I did get a lively and interesting game . 1 . d2-d4 2 . c2-c4

40. Gligoric-Szabo
(Ruy Lopez) The prime consideration in one ' s choice of an opening plan should be the harmonious devel opment of the pieces, but some times we forget about the devel opment of the queen. Since the queen is , after all , the most important and the most valuable of the pieces , the success of the whole piece configuration may depend on how well the queen plays its part . In some openings , the move a• . mcS is important not only as pawneances ntoef ra, ttacking the enemy but also in order to give the queen an exit to c 7 , b6 or aS . This applies es pecially to systems in which the bishop is developed to e7 , thus bgolnoackli:ngf ort heexaqumpeelne,' st hotehOerr tdhoia dox Queen' s Gambit , the Chigo rin Ruy Lopez, or the Class ical Variation of the French Defense . In the game Gligoric - Szabo, the development of Black' s queen became the central theme of the opening and middlegame struggle: White maintained a clear advan tage as long as the queen was relegated to the e ighth rank, and found his game s liding down hill as soon as the queen ob tained some lebensraum. 1 . e2-e4 2 . As a matter of fact , Black ' s chief ad vantage in this pos it ion lies not so much in his plus pawn, which he is still far from exploiting, as in his control of most of the center squares : d4, d5 , c5 , f4 and f5 . Smys lov, however , manages such endings with an iron hand . His plan may be divided in to the following phase s : ****** 1 . The immediate exchange of one rook, leavin9 the other to re strain White s queenside pawns and attack the c- and e-pawns . 2 . Deflecting White ' s rook to the h-f ile by the threat to cre ate an outs ide passed pawn, and then occupying the ,d-file with his own rook. 3 . Advancing the g-pawn to g4, undermining the e-pawn ' s sup port , which is the f3-pawn. 4 . Tying up White ' s pieces by attacking the e-pawn. 5 . Sending his king in to pick off the weak pawns . 80. Taimanov-Geller
(King 's Indian) Perusal of this meaty game will acquaint the reader with two strategic ideas . As a result of the opening Black obtains the pawn configuration c5-d6-e5 ver sus c4-d5-e4 ; this ensures White greater freedom to maneuver with in his own l ines , since he has three ranks , while Black has only two . This is an abstract advan tage , of course , but it is the master ' s task to render it con crete -- that is, to find a plan wherein this wil l prove useful. It is instructive to watch as Taimanov practically clears his first three ranks of pawns en tirely, enabling him to trans fer his forces easily from one wing to the other, while most of Black ' s pieces find themselves j ostling one another on the sev enth rank, and especially on the ****** easily while eighth. And the second idea: White doub les his rooks on the b-file , but cannot turn this to account , s ince al l the good invasion squares are covered by Black' s minor pieces . White therefore stirs up some play on the other wing; harmless in itself, this play leads to the exchange of a few pieces and draws the minor pieces away from the b-file , thus al lowing White ' s rooks to invade at b7 and con clude the game within a few moves . 1 . d2-d4 2 . c2-c4 3 . Some grandmasters , pos ses s ing the facu lty of quick cal cu lat ion, not infrequent ly give up a pawn or two s imp ly to al ter the nature and balance of a po s it ion , even if thi s is perhap s not in their favor . I don ' t think thi s manner of playing has much of a future . I myse l f have sacr ificed , al l to l d , several dozen pawns , but st i l l I think that the ma s ter who sacrifices a pawn ought to have at least a genera l idea of the nature of the ini t iat ive he wi l l thereby obtain , and what sort of game wi l l ensue . 172. Boleslavsky-Taimanov
(Queen's Indian Defense) Doe s White ge t the advantage from his right to the f irst move ? Every che s sp layer asks himself that que s t ion, and the answer i s not eas i ly discovered . One is forcefu l ly reminded in thi s connec tion of Vsevo lod Rau zer , one of our mo st noted mas ter- theore t ic ians , whose motto was , " 1 e2-e4 ! , and Whit e wins" . He was probab ly j oking when he said that , but every j oke con tains its share of truth . This conviction that moving the king ' s pawn f ir s t gave White the bet- ter of it , whi l e 1 d2-d4 led only to a draw , inspired Rauzer to work out amaz ing ly deep and forceful attacking systems in a number of openings : the S ic i lian , French, Ruy and Caro-Kann , and many others . Later , o f course , it deve l oped that many of his (291] wins owed le s s to the obj ec tive s trength of his 1 e2-e4 than to Rauzer ' s own creative talent , the except ional ly l ogical pat tern of h i s thinking , and the accuracy of his calculati ons . Rauzer ' s Attacks and Var iat ions l ive on, and are s t i l l emp loyed to this day , even though it i s po s s ible for B lack to defend him se l f succ e s s fu l ly agains t them. So working up forc ing l ines for use in the opening battle , a fear some weapon in the hand s o f such p layers as Morphy , Chigorin , Pi l l sbury , Alekhine , F ine and Botvinnik , i s a method that works equa l ly we l l f or White or B lack . The p layer who use s a prepared forc ing l ine may very we l l run into a f orced re futation, as in deed happened in some games from the pre sent t ournament . There i s n o playe r , pas t o r pre sent , who has never made a mis take - an axiom that ho lds j us t as true f or home analys i s as i t does for over- the -board play . Which , in turn , means that one cannot , as a ru l e , gain the advantage thi s way in the opening . S o there exi sts a d i fferent concept of opening s trat egy , which may briefly be summarized as f o l l ows : that it is not nec es sary to make the very be st move s - on ly good ones . This was the creat ive atti tude o f Lasker and Capab lanca , for examp le , and i t is Smys lov ' s too . The advantage o f the open ing , in this cas e , is unders t ood to be the right to choose a sys tem o f deve lopment more suited to the White p layer ' s taste , and which give s him the greatest pos s ible l iberty to express his creat ive abi l i ty . Stat i s tics - a sound approach to the s tudy of mas s phenomena - show that White ' s opening advan tage i s qui te real . In the var ious eras of his tory , in every strong tournament for which rec ord s were kept , White he ld a per s i s tent edge in the number of wins . Thi s advantage of White ' s should be cons idered as a ten dency , which manifests itself in the course o f dozens or hun dreds o f game s , but which has no bearing on the outcome o f any part icular game . I t wou ld be tremendous ly intere s t ing to ex- amine this tendency in hi stori cal cro s s - s ec t ion : has the per centage of games won by Wh ite increased or decreased by c om parison with what it was , say , 2 0 , 50 or 100 years ago ? One pecul iar feature should be noted : the stronger the tournament , the weaker the inf luence o f the ad vantage of the f irst move . As examp l es to demons trate this , one may c ite the 1948 Wor ld ' s Cham pionship Match-Tournament , the 1 9 5 1 World ' s Champ ionship Match ( in which White won f our game s and Black s ix ) , and a few other events .
